ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: A new student leads every seminar, except on days when there is a guest speaker.
Virtual first year seminar
none
Mostly virtual discussion/lecture content.
none
This was a first-year seminar.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Students leave the class with a good understanding of the history of Haiti and an in depth understanding of the topic they choose to base their final research paper on.

You learn a lot about the history of Haiti, how NGO's interact with Haitians today and some of the problems which Haitians face. There's a lot of discussion about what Haiti needs in order to develop sustainably, and what forms of aid are actually helpful.

I improved upon my ability to give clear, informative, and engaging presentations. I also learned so much more about the nation of Haiti than I previously knew. Finally, I practiced looking at an issue from a multidisciplinary perspective.

Writing abilities, knowledge of resources available at Yale, ability to find relevant academic works, as well as an insight into Haiti and into what working towards sustainability looks like and involves.
I broadened my knowledge about Haiti in various wide ranging areas of study, including its history and present. I improved my public speak by having to present to the class multiple times.
A small improvement in writing. Quite frankly I don't know why it's a writing credit. We received minimal feedback on our writing skills.
I learned the struggles faced by the Haitian people, exacerbated by environmental disasters. A large portion of the class also focused on working on our writing skills which was extremely beneficial.

I developed mostly writing skills and researching skills, but also spoken presentation skills. Both academic writing and creative writing can be practiced in this course, though it is mainly focused on academic and research based writing.
A much greater knowledge of the past and present of Haiti, in terms of its history, culture, environment, politics, ad economy, along with improved research/writing skills
How
how to present
During this course, I learned how to participate in discussions and prepare my research on a topic for my final paper.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The course is really really interesting. I loved the class. I liked the opportunity to prepare a seminar; I loved the two books assigned for reading; and I found Dr. Geballe to be really cordial. He cares about his students. 

The weaknesses of the course include: a lack of clarity on grades and having the student teach for the entire 1 hour 15 minute seminar is not as constructive as having a discussion planned for part of the seminar by the professor. The class could be improved if Dr. Geballe prepared at least half of the day's seminar and if he was much much clearer on grading.

There is extensive and helpful feedback for writing assignments. A number of seminars are run by students, which is very valuable but can also mean that how much you learn about each topic isn't always consistent. It's a very good class for learning about how to recognize and understand good information about Haiti online, in the libraries and so on.

A strength of this course are the discussions amongst students. The student-led presentations are informative, and many times I learned the most from my classmates' ideas. I also found the chosen textbooks and literature to be very helpful. 

It would be interesting to talk to more people who currently live in Haiti.

Through the course, I learned a lot about Haiti and I appreciated the time put towards thinking critically as a group about sustainable policies that could benefit Haiti. Overall, the structure was engaging and helpful.

This course provided lots of information from both the professor and through each student's research. The class was occasionally repetitive when each student would present on a different topic each class.
The feedback is weak.

Professor Geballe was highly engaging and my class mates provided a lot of insight to Haiti's situation, past and present. The reading material chosen was perfect for the course and the structure was fantastic in that it kept me on schedule the entire semester, all in preparation for the final project.
There was a lot of material and the way the assignments were scheduled helped tremendously with time management.

One of the strengths of this course was the size. With around 18 people, discussion was always possible and inputting your own ideas was easy. The professor was capable of truly getting to know at least a bit about each of the students.
I really appreciated the meetings after each paper submission
Weakness was the grades and how they were given was not explained to the class at all.
I believe that, after some time, the student-led courses were felt a little repetitive.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Breakout rooms and the discussion-based class format improved virtual engagement.

For the virtual setting, I thought the class went very well. Still having us lead classes and meet one-on-one to discuss our work over zoom was helpful. It was sometimes difficult to fully participate in discussion, especially with any technical issues, but I'm not sure that is an issue that can be resolved virtually.
I think this course overall succeeded during the pandemic. It did not pose many difficulties to surviving as a virtual course.
I think that given the pandemic, the instructor did a great job. The biggest challenge was our presentations, and that seemed to go fine.
The breakout rooms were helpful and the virtual discussions were honestly not bad for this class specifically. The one on one zoom meetings with the professor were very helpful.
I think the course was well adapted to the virtual format.
The synchronous virtual meeting format was great at facilitating engagement. I also greatly appreciated the numerous opportunities to meet with Professor Geballe outside of class.
I believe the student-led seminar succeeded.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Most definitely. If you are at all interested in learning the history of Haiti and how that relates to sustainability, I would recommend this class. The class is interesting, and Dr. Geballe is a great resource for student interested in environmental studies.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student! Especially if you want to think about issues of sustainability from a perspective you likely hadn't considered before. It's an interesting and valuable topic to learn about, and the class helps you develop writing and research skills.

Yes, I think it not only provides you with a background knowledge of Haiti's history and challenges you to think about how to manage NGO's, how to create clean water solutions, and how to solve other problems facing many societies today, but it is also a great introduction to Yale courses in general due to Professor Geballe's thoughtful guidance.
Yes. It was a great seminar to take during the first semester at Yale.

Yes, especially to first semester freshman. This course helped me transition into my first semester of college by writing my first papers at Yale and giving my first presentations here in front of other students.
No, the grading is strange and your writing doesn't improve.

I would recommend this course to others. It gave me a broader perspective on challenges faced by another country and the factors that influenced haiti's difficulties. I learned a lot and was able to experience many different opinions on the topic.

I would definitely recommend this course to other students. The topics covered along with the skills learned are well worth your time if you are at all interested in the environment or in just becoming a better writer.
Probably not. if you're interested in learning about haiti, it's probably best to do outside research. there's not much focus on haitian voices at all
Yes, to anyone who is interested in both Haiti and conservation.

Yes, definitely! This course was a wonderful deep-dive into every aspect of Haitian history, culture, and current issues. Professor Geballe is caring and supportive, and the class was well-structured to introduce students to Yale. You will improve your writing, public speaking, organizational skills, and even learn how to lead a class.
Yes was fun and not too much work
Yes, Prof. Geballe does well in introducing you to a Yale seminar.
